column1: 1996M&PS...31..116J|1996|Lithologic distribution and geologic history of the Apollo 17 site: The record in soils and small rock particles from the highland massifs|Jolliff
column8: Larry A.|Meteoritics and Planetary Science|31|1|116|Through analysis by instrumental neutron activation (INAA) of 789 individual lithic fragments from the 2 mm-4 mm grain-size fractions of five Apollo 17 soil samples (72443
column12: and 76503) and petrographic examination of a subset
column13: we have determined the diversity and proportions of rock types recorded within soils from the highland massifs. The distribution of rock types at the site
column14: as recorded by lithic fragments in the soils
column15: is an alternative to the distribution inferred from the limited number of large rock samples. The compositions and proportions of 2 mm-4 mm fragments provide a bridge between compositions of <1 mm fines
column16: and types and proportions of rocks observed in large collected breccias and their clasts. The 2 mm-4 mm fraction of soil from South Massif
column17: represented by an unbiased set of lithic fragments from station-2 samples 72443 and 72503
column19: 7% incompatible-trace-element-(ITE)-poor highland rock types (mainly granulitic breccias)
column25: the 2 mm-4 mm fraction of a soil from the North Massif
column26: represented by an unbiased set of lithic fragments from station-6 sample 76503
column27: has a greater proportion of ITE-poor highland rock types and mare-basalt fragments: it consists of 29% ITE-poor highland rock types (mainly granulitic breccias and troctolitic anorthosite)
column32: and 1% others. Based on a comparison of mass-weighted mean compositions of the lithic fragments with compositions of soil fines from all Apollo 17 highland stations
column33:
differences between the station-2 and station-6 samples are representative of differences between available samples from the two massifs.

From the distribution of different rock types and their compositions
column34: we conclude the following: (1) North-Massif and South-Massif soil samples differ significantly in types and proportions of ITE-poor highland components and ITE-rich impact-melt-breccia components. These differences reflect crudely layered massifs and known local geology. The greater percentage of impact-melt breccia in the South-Massif light-mantle soil stems from derivation of the light mantle from the top of the massif
column35: which apparently is richer in noritic impact-melt breccia than are lower parts of the massifs. (2) At station 2
column36: the 2 mm-4 mm grain-size fraction is enriched in impact-melt breccias compared to the <1 mm fraction
column37: suggesting that the <1 mm fraction within the light mantle has a greater proportion of lithologies such as granulitic breccias which are more prevalent lower in the massifs and which we infer to be older (pre-basin) highland components. (3) Soil from station 6
column40:
which is a component that is rare in station-2 South-Massif soils. (4) Compositional differences between poikilitic impact-melt breccias from the two massifs suggest broad-scale heterogeneity in impact-melt breccia interpreted by most investigators to be ejecta from the Serenitatis basin.

We have found rock types not previously recognized or uncommon at the Apollo 17 site. These include (1) ITE-rich impact-melt breccias that are compositionally distinct from previously recognized "aphanitic" and "poikilitic" groups at Apollo 17; (2) regolith breccias that are free of mare components and poor in impact melt of the types associated with the main melt-breccia groups
column42: if those groups derive from the Serenitatis impact
column43: may represent the pre-Serenitatis surface; (3) several VLT basalts
column44: including an unusual very-high-K basaltic breccia; (4) orange-glass regolith breccias; (5) aphanitic-matrix melt breccias at station 6; (6) fragments of alkali-rich composition
column46: and monzogabbro; (7) one fragment of 72275-type KREEP basalt from station 3; (8) seven lithic fragments of ferroan-anorthositic-suite rocks; and (9) a fragment of metal
column47: possibly from an L chondrite. Some of these lithologies have been found only as lithic fragments in the soils and not among the large rock samples. In contrast
column48: we have not found among the 2 mm-4 mm lithic fragments individual samples of certain lithologies that have been recognized as clasts in breccias (e.g.
column49:
dunite and spinel troctolite).

The diversity of lithologic information contained in the lithic fragments of these soils nearly equals that found among large rock samples
column50: and most information bearing on petrographic relationships is maintained
column51: even in such small samples. Given a small number of large samples for "petrologic ground truth
column52: small lithic fragments contained in soil scoop" samples can provide the basis for interpreting the diversity of rock types and their proportions in remotely sensed geologic units. They should be considered essential targets for future automated sample-analysis and sample-return missions.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1945-5100.1996.tb02061.x

column1: 1993LPI....24..725J|1993|A Monazite-bearing Clast in Apollo 17 Melt Breccia|Jolliff
column2: Bradley L.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference|||725|A phosphate-rich clast in a pigeonite-plagioclase mineral assemblage occurs in Apollo 17 impact-melt breccia 76503
column4: measuring 0.9 x 0.4 mm in thin section
column9: and trace monazite ((LREE)PO4). Major minerals include 26 percent pigeonite
column14: and other accessory minerals constitute less than 1 percent of the assemblage and Fe-metal occurs along fractures. Also present in the melt breccia as a separate clast is a fragment of felsite. Based on the association of these clasts and their assemblages
column15: a parent lithology of alkali-anorthositic monzogabbro is postulated. Monazite occurs in the phosphate-bearing clast as two less than 10 micron grains intergrown with whitlockite. The concentration of combined REE oxides in monazite is 63.5 percent and the chondrite-normalized REE pattern is strongly enriched in LREE
column17: 68 and terrestrial monazite. Thorium concentration was not measured in monazite
column18: but based on oxide analyses of approximately 100 percent (including interpolated values for REE not measured)
column19: substantial Th concentration is not indicated
column21: 68. Measured monazite/whitlockite REE ratios are La: 11
column25: and Yb: 0.5. Compositions of monazite and coexisting whitlockite and apatite are given.|

column1: 1993LPI....24..727J|1993|Apollo 17 Materials Viewed from 2-4 MM Soil Particles: Pre-Serenitatis Highlands Components|Jolliff
column4: Kaylynn M.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference|||727|Among the highland lithologies of 2-4 mm rock fragments in North Massif soil 76503
column5: we have found a compositional group
column7: that we interpret as representing the pre-Serenitatis surface. A component of these materials is an igneous-textured lithology that we believe formed in large impact melts. These are compositionally similar to
column9: many of the granulitic breccias that appear to be mixtures of ferroan and magnesian-suite rocks. The polymict
column12: along with granulitic breccias and the endogenous igneous lithologies found particularly at the North Massif stations
column13: constitute the poorly consolidated portions of North Massif. Highland samples from the South Massif
column15: are enriched in materials of the competent
column16: impact-melt breccias formed by the Serenitatis impact. The competent melt-breccias contain clasts of most of the pre-existing surface materials
column17: but they also contain components not found in the rocks of the poorly consolidated massif materials.|

column1: 1992ga17.conf...24J|1992|Possible Petrogenetic Associations Among Igneous Components in North Massif Soils: Evidence in 2-4-mm Soil Particles from 76503|Jolliff
column6: Larry A.|Geology of the Apollo 17 Landing Site|||24|Studies of Apollo 17 highland igneous rocks and clasts in breccias from the North and South Massifs have described magnesian troctolite
column11: and granulitic lithologies that may have noritic anothosite or anorthositic norite/gabbro as igneous precursors
column12: and have speculated on possible petrogenetic relationships among these rock types. Mineral compositions and relative proportions of plagioclase and plagioclase-olivine particles in samples 76503 indicate that the precursor lithology of those particles were troctolitic anorthosite
column13: not troctolite. Mineral and chemical compositions of more pyroxene-rich
column14: magnesian breccias and granulites in 76503 indicate that their precursor lithology was anorthositic norite/gabbro. The combination of mineral compositions and whole-rock trace-element compositional trends supports a genetic relationship among these two groups as would result from differentiation of a single pluton. Although highland igneous lithologies in Apollo 17 materials have been described previously
column15: the proportions of different igneous lithologies present in the massifs
column17: and how they are related are not well known. We consider the proportions of
column19: the igneous lithologies found in a North Massif soil
column20: which may represent those of the North Massif or a major part of it.|
